Views and Adaptors¶

  • Raw view
  • Drop view
  • Take view
  • Slice view

Raw view¶

The simplest view there is is the raw view. It is a non-owning wrapper around a sequence which models the view concept. Here’s a synopsis:

struct ... {
    ... // copy and move constructors and assignment operators

    static constexpr auto extent() noexcept ->std::ptrdiff_t;

    constexpr auto size() const noexcept ->std::size_t;

    constexpr decltype(auto) unsafe_at(std::size_t const i) const
      noexcept( whenever possible );

    constexpr decltype(auto) operator[](std::size_t const i) const;
};

The exact type, as well as constructors, is an implementation detail. For creation of raw views the following functor should be used.

constexpr auto boost::static_views::raw_view = implementation detail¶

\(\mathtt{raw\_view} : \mathtt{Sequence} \to \mathtt{View}\) (i.e. takes a sequence and returns a view). It will trigger static_assert failures if passed a type not modeling the sequence concept.

Here’s an example:

    // Some data
    constexpr int xs[] = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};

    // Works!
    auto const v1 = boost::static_views::raw_view(xs);

    // Error!
    // GCC: '... {(& xs)}' is not a constant expression
    // Clang: pointer to 'xs' is not a constant expression
    //
    // Indeed, 'xs' is a non-static constexpr variable that's stored
    // nowhere (except for the mind of the compiler).
    /* constexpr auto const v2 = boost::static_views::raw_view(xs); */

    // Solution? declare 'xs' as static
    static constexpr int ys[] = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};

    auto const           v3 = boost::static_views::raw_view(ys); // OK
    constexpr auto const v4 = boost::static_views::raw_view(ys); // OK

    // Check that the returned type models the View concept
    boost::static_views::concepts::View::check<decltype(v1)>();

Drop view¶

constexpr auto boost::static_views::drop = implementation detail¶

\(\mathtt{drop} : \mathbb{N} \to \text{View} \to \text{View}\) is a functor that let’s you create dropped views. Given a count \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) and a view \(xs\), creates a view of \(xs\) with the first \(n\) elements dropped. If the size of \(xs\) is less than \(n\), an empty view is returned.

constexpr auto boost::static_views::drop_exactly = implementation detail¶

\(\mathtt{drop} : \mathbb{N} \to \text{View} \to \text{View}\) is a functor that let’s you create dropped views. Very similar to drop, but has an extra precondition. When given a count \(n\) and a view \(xs\), it assumes that the size of \(xs\) is at least \(n\). If that’s not the case, an assertion failure is triggered.

Warning

If you disable the checks (i.e. define BOOST_STATIC_VIEWS_DISABLE_CHECKS) and pass an \(n > xs\mathtt{.size()}\), the behavior is undefined.

So if you created a variable auto v = drop(n)(xs), the following relation holds:

\[\mathtt{v[}i\mathtt{]} = \mathtt{xs[}i + n\mathtt{]} \;, \forall i \in \mathbb{N} \,.\]

Here’s a synopsis of v’s type:

struct ... {
    ... // copy and move constructors and assignment operators

    static
    constexpr auto extent() noexcept ->std::ptrdiff_t;

    constexpr auto size() const noexcept ->std::size_t;

    constexpr auto unsafe_at(std::size_t const) const& noexcept(whenever possible);
    constexpr auto unsafe_at(std::size_t const) &&     noexcept(whenever possible);

    constexpr auto operator[](std::size_t const) const&;
    constexpr auto operator[](std::size_t const) &&;

    constexpr auto map(std::size_t const) const noexcept ->std::size_t;

    constexpr auto parent() const& noexcept;
    constexpr auto parent() &&     noexcept;
};

There are two non-standard functions:

  • constexpr std::size_t map(std::size_t const i) noexcept¶

    Given an index i returns the corresponding index in the parent view. Let v be a drop view, then \(\forall i\in \{0,\dots,\mathtt{v.size()}-1\}: \mathtt{v[}i\mathtt{]} = \mathtt{v.parent()[} \mathtt{v.map(} i \mathtt{)]}\) For \(i \geq \mathtt{v.size()}\), the behavior of this function is undefined.

  • constexpr auto parent() noexcept¶

    Returns a reference to the parent view. In the auto v = drop(n)(xs) example, parent() returns xs.

Here’s an example of usage:

    // First of all, we need some view of the data
    static constexpr int  data[] = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
    static constexpr auto raw = boost::static_views::raw_view(data);

    // Now, let's create a view of raw with the first 3 elements
    // dropped
    constexpr auto v1 = boost::static_views::drop(3)(raw);

    // If you forget the step of creating the raw_view and write
    // constexpr auto v2 = boost::static_views::drop(3)(data);
    // ===> Error!
    // "static assertion failed: I'm sorry, but `View` must model the
    // View concept!"

    // Size is changed
    static_assert(raw.size() - 3 == v1.size(), "");

    // Though not the extent
    static_assert(raw.extent() == v1.extent(), "");

    // But if you _do_ want the extent to change as well, just pass
    // integral_constant rather than size_t to drop:
    constexpr auto v3 = boost::static_views::drop(
        std::integral_constant<std::size_t, 3>{})(raw);
    static_assert(raw.extent() - 3 == v3.extent(), "");

    // You can do all the common stuff like
    //
    // accessing elements
    static_assert(v1[1] == 5, "");
    // copying the view
    constexpr auto v4 = v1;
    // accessing the parent view
    static_assert(&raw == &v4.parent(), "");
    // etc.

Take view¶

constexpr auto boost::static_views::take = implementation detail¶

\(\mathtt{take} : \mathbb{N} \to \text{View} \to \text{View}\) is a functor that let’s you create take views. Given a count \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) and a view \(xs\), creates a view of \(xs\) consisting only of the first \(n\) elements of \(xs\). If the size of \(xs\) is less than \(n\), view of the whole \(xs\) is returned.

So if you created a variable auto v = take(n)(xs), the following relation holds:

\[\mathtt{v[}i\mathtt{]} = \mathtt{xs[}i\mathtt{]} \;, \forall i \in \{0,\dots,\mathtt{n}-1\} \,,\]

I.e. for \(i \leq \mathtt{n}\) take view behaves just like xs itself.

Here’s a synopsis of v’s type:

struct ... {
    ... // copy and move constructors and assignment operators

    static
    constexpr auto extent() noexcept ->std::ptrdiff_t;

    constexpr auto size() const noexcept ->std::size_t;

    constexpr auto unsafe_at(std::size_t const) const& noexcept(whenever possible);
    constexpr auto unsafe_at(std::size_t const) &&     noexcept(whenever possible);

    constexpr auto operator[](std::size_t const) const&;
    constexpr auto operator[](std::size_t const) &&;

    constexpr auto map(std::size_t const) const noexcept ->std::size_t;

    constexpr auto parent() const& noexcept;
    constexpr auto parent() &&     noexcept;
};

Like most of the views provided by the library, take view has map() and parent() member functions which are not, strictly speaking, required by the view concept.

  • constexpr std::size_t map(std::size_t const i) noexcept¶

    Given an index i returns the corresponding index in the parent view. Let v be a take view, then \(\forall i\in \{0,\dots,\mathtt{v.size()} - 1\}: \mathtt{v[}i\mathtt{]} = \mathtt{v.parent()[v.map(}i\mathtt{)]}\). For \(i \geq \mathtt{v.size()}\) the behavior of this function is undefined.

  • constexpr auto parent() noexcept¶

    Returns a eference to the parent view. In the auto v = take(n)(xs) example, parent() returns xs.

Here’s an example of usage:

    // First of all, we need a view of the data
    static constexpr int  data[] = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
    static constexpr auto raw = boost::static_views::raw_view(data);

    // Now, let's create a view of the first four elements of raw.
    constexpr auto v1 = boost::static_views::take(4)(raw);

    // If you forget the step of creating the raw_view and write
    // constexpr auto v2 = boost::static_views::take(4)(data);
    // ===> Error!
    // "static assertion failed: I'm sorry, but `View` must model the
    // View concept!"

    // Size is changed
    static_assert(v1.size() == 4, "");

    // Though not the extent
    static_assert(raw.extent() == v1.extent(), "");

    // But if you _do_ want the extent to change as well, just pass
    // integral_constant rather than size_t to take:
    constexpr auto v3 = boost::static_views::take(
        std::integral_constant<std::size_t, 4>{})(raw);
    static_assert(v3.extent() == 4, "");

    // You can do all the common stuff like
    //
    // accessing elements
    static_assert(v1[1] == 2, "");
    // copying the view
    constexpr auto v4 = v1;
    // accessing the parent view
    static_assert(&raw == &v4.parent(), "");
    // etc.

Slice view¶

constexpr auto boost::static_views::slice = implementation detail¶

\(\mathtt{slice} : \mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N} \to \text{View} \to \text{View}\) is a functor that let’s you create slices of views. Given a index \(b \in \mathbb{N}\), an index \(e \in \mathbb{N}\) and a view \(xs\), creates a view of elements of \(xs\) with indices \(i \in \mathbb{N} \cap [b, e)\).

Slice view is almost equivalent to a “take view of a drop view”, i.e. slice(b, e)(xs) is the same as take_exactly(e)(drop_exactly(b)(xs)). The almost comes from the map() and parent() member functions. Slice view is a single view and calling parent() will thus return xs. The “take view of view view” is a stack of two views – calling parent will return drop_exactly(b)(xs).

Here’s a synopsis of slice view:

struct ... {
    ... // copy and move constructors and assignment operators

    static
    constexpr auto extent() noexcept ->std::ptrdiff_t;

    constexpr auto size() const noexcept ->std::size_t;

    constexpr auto unsafe_at(std::size_t const) const& noexcept(whenever possible);
    constexpr auto unsafe_at(std::size_t const) &&     noexcept(whenever possible);

    constexpr auto operator[](std::size_t const) const&;
    constexpr auto operator[](std::size_t const) &&;

    constexpr auto map(std::size_t const) const noexcept ->std::size_t;

    constexpr auto parent() const& noexcept;
    constexpr auto parent() &&     noexcept;
};
  • constexpr std::size_t map(std::size_t const i) noexcept¶

    Given an index i returns the corresponding index in the parent view. Let v be a slice view, then \(\forall i\in \{0,\dots,\mathtt{v.size()} - 1\}: \mathtt{v[}i\mathtt{]} = \mathtt{v.parent()[v.map(}i\mathtt{)]}\). For \(i \geq \mathtt{v.size()}\) the behavior of this function is undefined.

  • constexpr auto parent() noexcept¶

    Returns a reference to the parent view. In the auto v = slice(b, e)(xs) example, parent() returns xs.
